advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPUTERS IN THE EXAM ROOM</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Laser 3000. For 5980F, play the double compatibility !"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MICROSOFT ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">No one knows better than Microsoft how to increase your TRS-80 BASIC's power. Microsoft created the TRS-80 Level ll and Disk BASIC plus the industry standard Microsoft BASIC...<br><br> ...Microsoft Level lll BASIC is an enhancement to the Level ll. It contains all Disk BASIC features not already in Level ll and it adds six new Level lll exclusives...<br> ...Advanced graphics is Level lll's most exciting addition to the TRS-80 - and it's exclusive. Draw a line, outline or solid box by specifying just two points, then save it and put it back with BASIC statement. You'll find yourself writing more programs with charts, graphs and even animation...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> Z-2H 1980 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an official advert from Hewlett-Packard. It says "The easy touch".</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>found on the system box</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. (AUG. 1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says: <br><br><font color="#666666"> In other words, how to pop your office into a shoulder bag and then go out and about.<br> You see the Sharp PC7000 is no ordinary computer. Not only it is light, compact body packed with a much speed and power as most desk top computers, it's also very, very versatile... </font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN AD #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Welcome in the world of the "clean"-computers"<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The ZX-81 will soon become a precious work tool"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 464 - 6128 PERIPHERALS</strong></font><br><blockquote>From top left to bottom right:<br> - T.V. modulator for the CPC 6128<br> - Joystick with joystick adaptor<br> - T.V. modulator for the CPC 464<br> - Disc drive with interface and CP/M for CPC 464<br> - Speech synthesizer and stereo amplifier<br> - Additional disc drive<br> - Light pen with graphics software<br> - RS232 interface<br> - DMP 2000 dot printer</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DAK ADVERT (US, 1986) - PAGE 2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.dak.com" target="_blank">DAK</a> for this advert</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (DEC. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"9990 francs the TO9. Colors included" <br><br> "Thomson. All the world in a present"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (DEC. 1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to David Wilson for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Computing is very simple with the AIM65 from Rockwell"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE - HAPPY COUPLE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.retrorene.nl/" target="_blank">Retro Rene's Gaming Corner</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD #1 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The major argument of the advert campaign was "we have a better and cheaper computer than Apple and IBM"...<br><br> True, but like many other computers of the time, the major fault of the Advantage was not to be an IBM system...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSERT - VERSO</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>''The European Alternative'' ! <br><br> The Basis 108 was sold in France by BMI. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> OEMS WANTED</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JULY 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Page 1</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href=§http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage§>Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>

computer.description:
The X68000 Pro is the successor of the X68000 Ace and Ace HD.
It uses a new version of the OS : Human 2.0 and a new Graphic User Interface (SX Windows instead of VS). It has 3 expansion slots instead of two.

emulator.description: X68000 emulator for linux and windows
emulator.name: Virtual X68000 Project

emulator.description: X68000 Emulator PPC is currently the only X68000 emulator available for the Macintosh
emulator.name: X68000 Emulator PPC

computer.name: X68000 Pro
computer.ports: Joystick (2), Audio IN / OUT, Stereo scope, TV Control, NTSC Video Image I/O, Expansion (3 slots), External FDD, SASI, RS232
computer.sound: FM Sound (Yamaha 2151 : 2 channels / 8 voices stereo) + PCM (OKI MSM6258V : 4 bit mono)
